column4: heya guys, anyone know on how to start a batch file on boot in ubuntu server?
add it in /etc/rc.local   add an ampersand at the end of the command and above the exit 0 line, itwill run as root at boot (unless you use su -c )
this will work http://pastebin.com/wdWTruhq ? if i add it to /etc/rc.local ?
you don't need the amperand on a line on it's own
so remove it from the batch file and will still run at boot as root?
yes, the ampersand backgrounds commands, so if you have one that never ends then it will hang the boot
yours won't do that, so you can leave it. All commands run as root in the file
i did this in my /etc/rc.local http://pastebin.com/0R0Ayk9h but it doesnt run on boot
the line you added does nothing, it's a folder
hmm how do i add it then? the batch file is called "batch03", i thought thats the right way
then delete the end slash, the script will then run
if the script runs forever, rather than firing once, add an ampersand to the end of the line, like so:  /home/testuser/scripts/batch03 &
i have part of the patch that adds a text to ipv6-status text file to confirm the script ran fine, it works if i run it manualy
did you add the absolute path of the file to update?
yes, it runs as root, so if you use ~ then that will be /root not /home/username
yes, the batch worked fine at boot, but this part didnt: echo IPv6 has been added at $(date) >> /home/testuser/ipv6-status
instead, try:    echo "IPv6 has been added at $(date)" | tee -a /home/testuser/ipv6-status
thanks alot dude, that did it!
for adding to files I suggest you use tee rather than >>. its a bit beater
just one last question, where do you think is the best location to put the batch file in?
wherever you want, there is no best. I like to make ~/.bin   and add it to PATH and use that for my user scripts. Its not best, just how I do it
